Colin, about your suggestion #2: Joseph Reisinger has done some 
interestin=
g work on varying the fitness function in order to get a 
more robust genet=
ic encoding.  The idea is that if the fitness 
function varies but there is=
 some underlying theme that is conserved 
(such as symmetry) the organisms =
will need to evolve to be able to 
represent that underlying theme efficien=
tly even though they can't 
rely on any particular instance of it.  This do=
es imply that 
calamities can lead to robustness, but it appears than an im=
portant 
ingredient in such a system is an encoding that can encapsulate 
i=
nformation about underlying themes, i.e. an indirect encoding.  
Here's the=
 paper:

http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?reisinger:gecco05

ken

differ=
ent

n=
etwoks

the best

t 
functions

hen 
could be

and 
changing

nction has a bunch of measures that are weighted
